question:
Study the diagrams below

 

     

 

(a) ldentify the implements represented by diagrams l and ll above.

(b) List three important parts of each of the implements illustrated by diagrams I and lI

(c) State one function of each of the parts of the implements listed in (b)

(d) State:(i) one major advantage in using the implement illustrated by Il:
(ii) one major disadvantage in using the implement illustrated by I.
answer:
(a) Implement I is Mould board plough/ plow while implement lI is Disc plough /plow.

(b) Important parts of each are:

  • I - Coultier /vertical disc; shore / share point mould board: beam/frame; standard.
  • II - Concave disc / disc: sledge / knife / scrapper, rotating hubs disk bearing bearing: spring: beam / frame, balancing disc / furrow wheel; beam cap; coupling point / hinge / linkage point, Standard

(c) Function of each part listed; 

I;

  • Coulter makes vertical cuts/furrows;
  • Share makes horizontal cuts/uproot weeds;
  • Mould board carries the soil, inverts the weeds and exposes the roots of the weeds;
  • Standard bears the mouldboard and Share
  • Beam/Frame carries the plough and other components / proves additional weight for greater depth

II;

  • Concave disc rotates and makes vertical cuts / horizontal cuts as the tractor moves forward / inverts the soil.
  • Scrapper /knife/sledge helps to remove soils that cling to the disc.
  • Hub helps the dick to overcome obstacles like rocks. outcrops, stumps etc;  
  • Frame / Bame holds discs in position and bears additional weight for greater depth
  • Furrow wheel /balancing disc - balances the plough / keeps plough from toppling:
  • Coupling point provides point of attachment to the tractor;
  • Standard carries the disc and other associated parts.

(d) Advantages of Disc plough (ii) are:

  • It overcomes obstacles like stones and stumps more readily.
  • lt can be used in more difficult soils, e.g. clay or sticky soils.

Disadvantages of Mould board plough are

  • It loses its share point when in contact with an obstruction.
  • It predisposes soil to erosion / soil compaction takes place when used often.

question:
The diagram below illustrates the experimental setup used to determine soil texture.

(a) Name the parts labelled A to F on the diagram.

(b) List four major constituents of the soil

(c) State three other methods which can be used to determine soil texture

(d) Explain briefly two importance of soil texture to the farmer
answer:
(a) Parts labeled A - F are;

  • A - Floating organic materials;
  • B -Water;
  • C - clay / clay particles;
  • D - Silt,
  • E - fine sand / sand
  • F - Coarse sand / gravel / small stones

(b) Major constituents of soil are;

  • Minerals - sand, clay etc;
  • Organic matter;
  • Water
  • Air;
  • Micro organisms.

(c) Other methods of determining soil texture are;

  • Feelíng method by rubbing soil between thumb and the fingers
  • Moulding into rings when wet.
  • Sieve method. 
  • Pipette method.
  • Hydrometer method.

(d) Importance of soil texture to the farmer:

  • useful in the evaluation of soil,
  • ability to supply mineral nutrients,
  • support of soil micro organisms essential for plant growth,
  • determines the relative proportion of air and water in the soil,
  • determines movement of air and water in the soil,
  • helps to determine the type of crops to be planted or to grow,
  • helps to determine tillage practice to be adopted by the farmer.

question:
(a) Identify the fruit illustrated by the diagram below

(b) Name the parts labelled A to D.

(c) Outline briefly the processes or stages involved in the cultivation of the fruít illustrated in the diagram.
answer:
(a) The fruit is Coconut fruit / Oil palm fruit.

(b) Parts labelled A - D are:

  • Á -Epicarp / Exocarp;
  • B- Mesocarp / husk;
  • C- Endocarp/shell;
  • D - Kernel / coconut kernel / Endosperm /seed:

(c)(i) Stages of cultivation / Steps of production for Coconut fruit are:

  • Plant coconut fruits in nursery at a spacing of 30 -60 cm x 30 -60cm,
  • water and weed regularly,
  • prepare the land through cleaning, burning, and stumping.
  • Dig planting holes infield at 8m x 8m spacing and transplant the seedlings.
  • Add fertilizer/ manure for good growth, weed, water, and control pests and disease when necessary. OR

(ii) Stages of cultivation for oil palm fruit are;

  • pre-germination of kernels in seedbox and planting pre-germinated seedlings in the nursery.
  • Water and weed regularly as required.
  • Land preparation, clearing, burning, stumping.
  • Digging holes at 9m x 9m spacing.
  • Transplanting of seedlings.
  • Add manure / fertilizer for good growth.
  • weed when necessary.
  • water when necessary.
  • control pests and diseases when necessary

(d) Industrial uses of Coconut or oil palm fruit.

Coconut fruit;

  • husk used in manufacture of foot mats / brushes.
  • cake for livestock feeding.
  • shell Used for fuel.
  • copra used in manufacture of coconut oil.
  • oil used in making creams/ soap/ margarine.
  • coconut milk used for alcohol production.
  • Biscuits.

Oil palm fruit;

  • Husk used for fuel.
  • Oil used for soup/margarine / cosmetics.
  • Shell used for fuel.
  • cake used for livestock feed.
  • oil used for candle production.
  • kernel used for production of palm kernel oil.
